entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 31 at 2:47AM PDT until March 31 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 6 to 10 feet with local sets to 12 feet and dangerous rip currents. Surf will be highest on west and northwest facing beaches.
* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches and Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM PDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Beaches; Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM PDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 31 at 4:33AM CDT by NWS Corpus Christi TX
entry.summary:
Areas of fog have developed across portions of South Texas this morning. Expect visibilities generally 3 to 5 miles or less. Patchy dense fog, with visibilities 1/4 mile or less, will also occur at times.
Use caution if traveling as visibility may change rapidly within a short period of time. Use low beam headlights and leave extra distance between your vehicle and the vehicles of other motorists on the road.
entry.cap:areaDesc: McMullen; Live Oak; Bee; Goliad; Victoria; Duval; Jim Wells; Inland Kleberg; Inland Nueces; Inland San Patricio; Inland Refugio

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 31 at 3:32AM MDT until March 31 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT TODAY FROM 10 AM THROUGH 7 PM MDT FOR NORTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY...
.Critical fire weather conditions develop once again today across eastern NM. Minimum relative humidity values below 15 percent and strong southwest winds will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. The strongest winds will materialize in the afternoon with peak gusts of 45 to 55 mph most areas, with the gusts of 60+ mph expected along the northeast highlands.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Plains (Zone 104), Northeast Highlands (Zone 123), Central Highlands (Zones 125) and the East Central Plains (Zone 126) this afternoon through early evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 35 to 45 mph with gusts to between 50 and 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 15 percent each day.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Northeast Highlands; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM THIS MORNING TO 7 PM MDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 31 at 3:07AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
A passing disturbance will continue to maintain periods of light snow over Southwest Montana through at least the morning hours. While areas of higher terrain will observe the most persistent snow, lower elevations including Bozeman, Dillon, and Ennis have received measurable snow as well. Snowfall accumulations will mostly remain less than one inch, but localized areas may see heavier amounts up to a few inches.
Anyone traveling should be prepared for variable winter road conditions including reduced visibility down to a half mile or less and slippery roadways. Slow down, leave plenty of room between your vehicle and the one in front of you, and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Big Belt, Bridger and Castle Mountains; Elkhorn and Boulder Mountains; Missouri Headwaters; Madison River Valley; Gallatin Valley; Northwest Beaverhead County; Beaverhead and Western Madison below 6000ft; Ruby Mountains and Southern Beaverhead Mountains; Gallatin and Madison County Mountains and Centennial Mountains

cap:parameter.value: Periods of light snow will impact much of Southwest Montana through the morning hours

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 31 at 2:50AM MDT until March 31 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 013 Sherman, 027 Wallace, 028 Logan, 041 Greeley, 042 Wichita, 253 Kit Carson and 254 Cheyenne.
* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 14 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The relative strongest winds are expected to occur generally along and west of the Colorado/Kansas border. Confidence in Red Flag Warning criteria being met in Sherman, Wallace and Wichita counties is a bit less compared to points to the west as winds may not switch to the southwest which would create higher relative humidity and non critical fire weather conditions.

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued March 30 at 5:13PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
SABCO
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...SPECIAL AVALANCHE ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM MONDAY...
*WHAT...New snow and strong winds are building thick slabs of snow over a recently buried weak layer creating unusually dangerous avalanche conditions.
*WHERE...West Elk and Elk Mountains including the Ruby and Ragged Ranges
*WHEN...Through Monday evening
*IMPACTS...Large, dangerous avalanches are easy to trigger. Avalanches will run naturally above treeline, and some can step down to deeper weak layers resulting in a more destructive avalanche.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Avoid avalanche terrain above treeline. In other areas, cautious route-finding and conservative decision-making are essential to travel safely in the backcountry on Sunday and Monday. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 30 at 2:15PM PDT until March 31 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Moderate to heavy snow to continue. Additional snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches expected for elevations above 6000 feet and 2 to 6 inches for elevations between 4500 and 6000 feet. Southwest winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 40 mph through tonight.
* WHERE...Interior Mountains of Los Angeles, Ventura, and Santa Barbara Counties.
* WHEN...Until 11 PM PDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous driving conditions due to icy roads and poor visibility. These conditions could lead to road closures and significant travel delays. There is also an increased risk for avalanches over the higher peaks.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 30 at 3:08PM MDT until March 31 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Intermittent snow showers this afternoon will become more widespread after 9PM. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches. Higher amounts in excess of 6 inches will be possible under localized heavy snow bands.
* WHERE...Much of Carbon and Albany counties including Rawlins, Saratoga, Arlington, Elk Mountain, Shirley Basin, and the North Laramie Range.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM MDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Hazardous travel conditions due to icy, snow packed roads and reduced visibilities in moderate to heavy snow.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow totals are expected to be highly variable due to the banded nature of the snowfall. Conditions may change significantly over very short distances.
entry.cap:areaDesc: North Laramie Range; Ferris/Seminoe/Shirley Mountains; Shirley Basin; Central Carbon County; North Snowy Range Foothills; Southwest Carbon County; Upper North Platte River Basin

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 30 at 1:17PM PDT until March 31 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in San Diego CA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in California...
San Diego River At Fashion Valley affecting San Diego County.
For the San Diego River...including Fashion Valley...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...San Diego River at Fashion Valley.
* WHEN...From this evening to tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 7.5 feet, Action stage. The first real impacts are seen on the San Diego River at this level. Low lying roads in and around Fashion Valley Mall begin to take on water. Avenida Del Rio is the first road to begin flooding. At 9.0 feet, More extensive low lying road flooding begins in and around Fashion Valley including Fashion Valley Road. Parking structures in and around Fashion Valley Mall can begin to take on water at the lowest levels. At 10.0 feet, More extensive flooding begins at this level, more than just low lying areas. Fashion Valley Mall parking garage is taking on water at the lower levels, with 1 to 2 feet of water in the garage. Water on the Town and Country hotel parking lot adjacent to the river and USGS gage. At 11.0 feet, The parking garages in Fashion Valley Mall can have up to 3 feet of water on the lowest levels. Water may begin to surround area hotels such as the River Leaf Inn. The Mission Trolley Station on Ward Road may begin to flood. Flooding begins on Camino De La Reina (under Highway 163). At 12.0 feet, Even more extensive road flooding occurs in and around Mission Valley. Qualcomm Way, Camino Del Este, Ward Road, and Mission Gorge Rd flooded. Mission Trolley Station flooded and may close due to flowing water. I-5 on and off ramps flooded at the San Diego River and Pacific Highway. Mission Center Road may begin flooding with debris on railings. Fashion Valley Trolley Station surrounded by water. 2 feet of water flowing over Fashion Valley Road across gates. Old golf course has been flooded at this level.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:59 PM PDT Saturday the stage was 6.4 feet and rising. - Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage late this evening to 10.1 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then remain near flood stage through this evening and through much of Sunday as well. The river will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO TOMORROW EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 11:48AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: Southerly winds will increase south of Kodiak Island and out of the northwest across the southern Alaska Peninsula this afternoon as a strong storm system moves northwards towards Kodiak Island. As the area of low pressure moves north of Kodiak, winds will shift to the southwest, peaking this evening before gradually decreasing through Sunday morning. Areas near Chignik and lower elevations of Kodiak Island, including Kodiak City, could see wind gusts up to 55 mph.

cap:parameter.value: STRONG WINDS DEVELOPING LATE THIS AFTERNOON/EVENING FOR THE FAR EASTERN ALASKA PENINSULA AND KODIAK ISLAND
